tldr:
Many real-world datasets involve discretized variables, which are approximations of underlying continuous variables. Existing methods for testing conditional independence (CI) struggle with discretized data, often leading to inaccurate conclusions about the relationships between variables. This is problematic for tasks like causal discovery and building graphical models, where accurate CI assessments are crucial. 
This paper introduces a novel method, called DCT, to address the limitations of existing CI tests when dealing with discretized data. The key is to use bridge equations to recover the relationships between latent continuous variables and their discretized counterparts. DCT also incorporates nodewise regression to efficiently estimate the precision coefficients for CI testing. Extensive experiments demonstrate that DCT significantly outperforms existing methods across several datasets, including real-world applications, highlighting its effectiveness and robustness.
